photo.description: So I'm walking through al-Aqsa mosque a few minutes before Eid al-Adha salaat in Jerusalem, Israel on the Temple Mount, when all of a sudden *plop* a peice of candy hits me. I look at it, confused. "Is someone throwing candy at me because they know me from somewhere, or because they want me and my big camera out of the area?" I felt a little bad for possibly intruding, but I wasn't doing anything wrong, so I kept walking farther into the mosque to get closer to the front. When I sat down, I noticed the above photograph: a dude throwing candy at everyone. I laughed. No one was targeting me! I was just being given candy for Eid! (in a very direct manner...). Later outside, I was handed more candy by an elderly lady. We also got four small bananas on the Temple Mount. Randomly. haha.

photo.description: The al-Aqsa Mosque (705 CE) is part of the third holiest place in Islam and is constantly being updated. When we went during Eid al-Adha, there were numerous scaffolding inside the mosque fixing the ceiling and walls. In fact, nearly every ceiling (in the five aisles) were different. There were vaulted ceilings, flat ceilings, ceilings with wooden panels and coffered ceilings (thank Islamic Art/Architecture at AUC for that last bit of knowledge!) But after 1,300 years, a mosque like this needs to be maintained... unfortunate though that one as historic as this isn't nearly as in great shape as the first two holy sights. The funniest thing about this mosque is that even though it's 1,300 years old and one of the holiest places in Islam... the architecture is SO sloppy! Arches don't line up, capitals are smushed, ceilings are lopsided... it's rather interesting.

photo.description: After Eid prayer, we wanted to get a photo of all three of us in front of the Dome... a task easier said than done. I think I brought my retractable tripod with me (I say I think because I take it with me everywhere but it's mysteriously absent from this photograph) but we decided to ask a random person to photograph us. Kiran told me to go up to a group of people to the right, and although I hesitated at first (I said they wouldn't get the Dome in the shot and just have a photo of us) I went to them and asked if someone could take our picture. A boy jumps up, all excited, he comes with me. "Of all people, you chose the little boy?" Kiran says. He was all excited, how could I say no to him? So I give him the camera and walk to the girls and we wait. But before we were able to fix our hair (actually, I was the only one doing the hair fixing) a girl who I assume is his sister comes running up to take the photo instead. The boy looked sad, but perhaps it was a wiser decision? And what do you know? The first frame had no dome. So I guess not all judgements are bad judgements? It was a nice frame of us, but we needed to have the Dome in it! I told her. So this is her second shot. It's actually quite beautifully composed! I wish I had her e-mail or something because it really is a great photograph, great lighting and great clouds (but I don't think she had as much to do with those two things as much as the big guy we were praying to that Eid). So thanks! Whoever you are! A final Eid Mubarak to you all!

photo.title: Jerusalem

photo.description: Never quite understood the geometry til I visited & saw it for myself. The Temple Mount is a huge rectangular platform that constitutes the top of Mount Moriah. It was constructed in stages, but in its present incarnation -- Herod's massive expansion of the preexisting Second Temple -- the irregular natural mountaintop was leveled, using the parts that stuck up to fill in the parts that sloped down. This fill was contained by massive stone retaining walls. The temple itself then sat atop this platform. At the center of the temple was the bedrock outcropping that constituted the most sacred part (the Foundation Stone; among other things, the site of Abraham's intended sacrifice of Isaac). So the Western Wall is one of the four walls. And the part you see here is ~1/4 the length and maybe half the height. It continues far below the present ground level. There used to be a wadi bordering the mount here, the Tyropean Valley. It was filled in by the Mameluks, as by that time it had ceased to be a useful natural defensive perimeter and become instead an inconvenient barrier between the Mount and the rest of the city. The large blocks are Herod's original construction -- you can see the characteristic dressed edges of the Herodian ashlars. (The lower couple of courses of stones visible here were below ground until recently, so they are particularly well preserved.) Above that is reconstruction dating from the Fatimid and Ommayid periods. The temple was destroyed by the Romans in 69 CE, leaving behind only the platform. Then after the Islamic conquest, the Dome of the Rock was built over the sacred outcropping and Al Aqsa Mosque in the near corner. So the top of the Temple Mount is given over to the Moslems now, and Jews worship at the wall below (which is why they've had trouble with Moslems stoning the Jews from above). In theory the top of the Temple Mount is open to the public; in practice, we were warned to avoid it.
photo.tags: jerusalem israel westernwall kotel hakotel hakotelhamaarivi plaza templemount archaeology herodian
photo.title: The Western Wall

photo.title: The Wailing Wall with Al Aqsa Mosque

photo.description: Also known as the Temple Mount by the Jews, this is the site in Jerusalem where two of the three main monotheistic religions intersect... and is the center of the biggest ownership issue in the world. At the top of the "Mount" sits the third holiest site in Islam (after al-Haram in Makkah and al-Nabawi in Medina): the Dome of the Rock and the al-Aqsa Mosque complexes. Originally, this is the area to which Muslims used to face in prayer five times a day until Muhammad (saw) took over Makkah in 630 and removed the idols from inside the Ka'ba. It is also the site that both religions recognize as the place where the Prophet Abraham attempted to sacrifice his son Isaac. And lastly, and most importantly for Muslims, it is the site (now located inside the Dome of the Rock) to where Muslims believe the Prophet Muhammad was transported from Makkah before ascending to heaven, meeting many of the past prophets and discussing with God how many times the Muslims are supposed to pray each day. For those who are religious, I urge you to look up the story if you don't already know it because it is quite a wonderful one. Along the "Mount" stands the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall. This is the holiest site in Judaism and has been an area of pilgrimage for Jews for nearly 1,700 years. The Wall is what remains of the surrounding walls of the First and Second Temples, both of which were the holiest sites in Judaism during their respective times before being destroyed by the Babylonians and the Romans, respectively, by the time of the Prophet Jesus. And while the place the Jews visit is in the center of the photograph, the Western Wall still technically runs all along the Old City, even along the sides of houses and alleys -- there's even an area known as the Mini Western Wall with a few prayers stuffed into the wall's cracks. To the Muslims, the Western Wall is the area that Muhammad ropes the winged horse named Buraq while leading Abraham, Moses, Jesus and other prophets in prayer before his ascent to heaven. At the moment, Jerusalem and the Noble Sanctuary / Temple Mount is controlled by Israel, but both Israeli and Palestinian sides seek ownership of the location. This location is the most visual and stark reminder that this city of Jerusalem is beloved by both Muslims and Jews and that both religions live and thrive among one another here. Yet, like they are when they visit their Noble Sanctuary or Temple Mount alike -- whichever name you politcally want to call it by -- they are so close to each other, but are mentally so far away. And for what it's worth, for those who have toured Jerusalem, you might be with me when I say: just give the Christians authority over the city! -- they have way more history in Jerusalem and the neighboring Bethlehem than Islam and Judaism combined! :P
photo.title: The Noble Sanctuary in Jerusalem

photo.description: Kiran, Sofi and I head down to the Temple Mount in Old City Jerusalem to pray in the Dome of the Rock / al-Aqsa Mosque for Eid al-Adha. The streets of Jerusalem cannot be compared to any other location I've seen... steps, steps steps. Stones, stones, stones. Shops, shops, shops. It's both quite beautifully ancient as well as somewhat disorienting. There are often times opposites walking down the streets. A Hasidic Jew walking side by side (though not talking) with a Muslim Sheikh. But in this photo, two Muslims walk in the same direction... but with very different expressions. I very, very much enjoyed their company :D

photo.description: Western Wall, Jerusalem The holiest place of the Jewish people, this Wall is venerated as the last remnant of the Holy Temple. The fervor displayed by the men coming to pray here – the women have a separate section of the Wall – is quite impressive. The politics surrounding the Western Wall are even more turbulent and are pretty representative of the ongoing conflict in the region, as well. Technically part of East Jerusalem, if a Palestinian state were to be created with this city as capital, the Wall would find itself under Palestinian control, which is very much unacceptable to the Israeli. The fact that the Dome of the Rock and Al-Aqsa mosques stand but a few meters away and above the wall means that Palestinians aren't ready to make any concessions on this, either.

photo.description: Otherwise known as the Al-Aqsa Mosque
photo.tags: domeoftherock israel jerusalem middleeast oldcity palestine summer templemount alaqsa mosque
photo.title: The Dome of the Rock, Jerusalem

photo.description: ~ 690 CE On the Temple Mount / Noble Sanctuary in Jerusalem, this building (along with the nearby al-Aqsa Mosque) is the third holiest in Islam (after the Ka'ba in Mecca and the Prophet's -- saw -- Mosque in Medina). Muslims believe that the rock inside the building is the location from where Muhammad ascended to heaven one night, while meeting a number of prophets along the way. There is a story that when Muhammad was rising up, the ground wanted to rise with him, but the Angel Gabriel told the ground its place was on Earth and so a small cave was created -- that cave is still existant today inside the Dome. To the Jews, the foundation stone of the Temple Mount, above the cave, is the holiest site in Judaism along with the nearby Western Wall. They face towards it everyday while in prayer.

photo.description: Dome of the Rock on the Temple Mount in Old Jerusalem. We were fortunate enough to get inside Al-Aqsa Mosque, the third most holy site in Sunni Islam. I also got to stick some prayers in the Wailing Wall just a few steps away.
photo.tags: israel middleeast jerusalem oldcity
photo.title: Mosque

photo.description: The iconic dome of al-Aqsa is the above-ground part -- but the bumps in the courtyard in front of it are skylights for a huge new underground mosque, el-Marwani. It was constructed 1996-99, using bulldozers to excavate a huge volume of the Temple Mount -- utterly without regard for the destruction of irreplaceable archaeological materials. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excavations_at_the_Temple_Mount#Con... is the Wikipedia section on it, & en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Temple_mount_works.jpg is a photo of the bulldozers at work. Then, in 2002, a structural bulge of almost a meter was discovered in the south (lefthand) wall of the Temple Mount. A team of Jordanian engineers was brought in to repair the damage. While they were doing the work, either they or the Palestinian laborers working with them carved the word "Allah" into the ancient stones of the Temple Mount in meter-high letters. Israeli archaeologists have mounted a sifting operation to salvage artifacts from the 300 truckloads of earth that was removed during the mosque construction & dumped in the adjacent valley. But of course even for individual items that survived the bulldozers, the all-important stratigraphic data have been irretrievably lost.
photo.tags: jerusalem israel mountofolives templemount alaqsa alaqsamosque mosque dome minaret elmarwanimosque elmarwani underground archaeology destruction
photo.title: One mosque? Look closer!

photo.title: The blessed game

photo.description: This shot is from the roof of the Petra Hotel, just at sundown. I like the rhythm of domes & towers, large & small. Jerusalem lacked a source of timber for roof beams (especially after the deforestation by the Ottomans), so stone domes were often used for the structural spans of ordinary roofs. The silvery dome in the foreground is the Church of St John the Baptist, and the gold one is of course the Dome of the Rock. The tower next to the Dome of the Rock is the minaret of Al Aqsa mosque. The one on the Mount of Olives behind is the Russian Convent and Church of Ascension. Hmm... so to look at the place, you might think there's nobody here except Christians & Muslims! Interesting that the 2 proselytizing religions both build towers whose purpose is to announce themselves by both sight and sound (the church bells & the call to prayer). The minarets are even more visible after dark, as they sport green lights. And to think I had picked the photo just for its composition...
photo.tags: jerusalem israel omarsquare jaffagate petrahotel domes towers steeples minarets roof cityscape
photo.title: Domes & towers
